name.text: 9.3.8 (Proof of partial fractions for two linear factors)

questiontext.text:
In order to be able to use partial fractions in this way, we need to know that such a decomposition always exists. Fortunately we can prove this as follows.


Suppose we want to write the partial fractions decomposition for \(\dfrac{mx+c}{(x-a)(x-b)}\).


Lemma: We can always find \(A\) and \(B\) such that \(\dfrac{mx+c}{(x-a)(x-b)}=\dfrac{A}{x-a}+\dfrac{B}{x-b}\).


Proof:

Combining the right-hand side into a single term, we need: \[ \dfrac{mx+c}{(x-a)(x-b)}=\dfrac{A(x-b)+B(x-a)}{(x-a)(x-b)}=\dfrac{(A+B)x-Ab-Ba}{(x-a)(x-b)} \] so by comparing the numerators we see that \(A\) and \(B\) must satisfy \[ \begin{eqnarray*} A+B&=&m \\ -Ab-Ba&=&c \end{eqnarray*} \] Solving this system of equations, we find \[ A= -\dfrac{am+c}{b-a},\quad B=\dfrac{bm+c}{b-a} \] So we can always find \(A\) and \(B\) to make this work, provided that \(a-b\neq0\).


Note that this proof tells us nothing about the case where \(a=b\), that is, w e have only shown, so far that a partial fraction decomposition exists for a fraction with two linear, distinct factors in its denominator. In fact, we can form partial fractions for a wider range of rational functions, which we will see shortly.
